 HUNGARY QUICK START GAS TURBINE PROJECT Loan and Project Summary Borrower: MVM Rt (Hungarian Power Companies Ltd.) Guarantor: Republic of Hungary Amount: US$60 million Terms: 15 years, including 5 years of grace, at the Bank's standard variable interest rate for LIBOR-based US dollar single currency loans. Project Objectives: The objective of the Project is to provide about 220 MW of generation reserve capacity to enable Hungary to maintain a high level of reliability and security of supply. The Project would in particular enable Hungary to meet the operating standards in effect in Western Europe, as set out by UCPTE, to which MVM's system is interconnected. Through membership in UCPTE, MVM benefits, inter alia, from system reserves shared by all members. Furthermore, the Project will allow Hungary to enhance its role as a transit country for electricity trade in Europe between the North and South, as well as the East and the West. Project Description: The proposed project consists of two complete single cycle gas turbine power plants rated 110 MW each burning light distillate fuel oil. The plants will consist of: (i) gas turbine generator sets and auxiliaries, air inlet and exhaust gas systems, including stacks; (ii) electrical equipment, as required to serve the plants' needs; (iii) power plant control systems; (iv) high voltage switchgear and unit transformers to connect the generator sets to the 120-kV system; and (v) ancillary facilities. Project Benefits: The project is justified in terms of overall system needs, as it enters the national least cost expansion program as early as 1998. A comparison with alternative solutions, such as electricity imports and a pumped storage plant, indicates that gas turbines represent the least cost means of providing secondary reserves. The economic internal rate of return calculation, in which the expected average wholesale capacity charges were taken as a measure of willingness to pay for project benefits, resulted in an EIRR of 16%, which is satisfactory; various sensitivity analyses concluded that the EIRR is quite robust under all the scenarios tested.

In addition, MVM faces different types of financial risks particularly since it operates on thin profit margins, and is committed to long term electricity purchases and sales agreements. The Economy 1.1 Hungary is an upper-middle income country with a GNP per capita of US$3,840 in 1994 for a population of 10.3 million. Hungary experimented with market-type reforms much earlier than the other formerly centrally planned economies. The "New Economic Mechanism", introduced in 1968, aimed at substituting market prices for the central plan as an allocative mechanism. The pace of reform was significantly accelerated in the late 1980s. These efforts were successful in building up some of the basis of the legal and institutional framework of a market economy. However, the authorities did not respond appropriately to the emergence of internal and external disequilibria, as indicated by the increase of the overall fiscal deficit to 7.1% of the GDP and of the current account deficit to 9.2% of GDP in 1993-94. Inflation was running at about 20% per year. Up to early 1995, the all-encompassing welfare system inherited from communism was left virtually intact, and two-thirds of the State assets remained to be privatized. 1.2 In March 1995, the Hungarian Government announced a set of measures aimed at stabilizing the economy, including substantial cuts in fiscal expenditures, increases in fiscal revenues, devaluation of the forint, followed by a pre-announced crawling peg, and a strict wage policy. These measures contributed to a significant improvement in the country's external position. Despite a strong fiscal contraction, a slight recovery in GDP has been sustained. The Government's resolve to consolidate the stabilization efforts was clearly reflected in the implementation of the 1996 Central Government budget. This budget resulted in a significant contraction in the General Government deficit, from 6.7% of GDP in 1995 to 4.0% of GDP in 1996, and drove Hungary's current account deficit to around US$1.8 billion (4.1 %), or very close to its long-run target. The stabilization program is being supported by an IMF Stand-By loan (approved in March 1996), but so far Hungary has not drawn on this loan. 1.3 The stabilization measures have been accompanied by an invigoration of structural reforms, including an acceleration of the privatization of state-owned banks and enterprises. These efforts resulted, in the second half of 1995, in privatization of large utilities and transfer to private investors of two of the large state-owned banks. Due to these sales, foreign direct investment in 1995 increased to a record volume of more than US$4.0 billion (9.0% of GDP). The Government is continuing to implement a comprehensive and in-depth program of structural measures, designed to complete the enterprise and banking sector reforms.

Reserves are estimated at 0.7 billion tons of hard coal (200 MM toe), 1.0 billion tons of brown coal (250 MM toe), and 3.0 billion tons of lignite (500 MM toe). Power generation utilities, now often integrated with the coal mines, account for all the lignite production, and approximately 70% of the hard and brown coal mined in Hungary. Uranium reserves at 7 million tons are sufficient to meet the requirement of the PAKS nuclear power plant during its expected lifetime. Other Ministries concerned with the sector include the Ministries of Finance and Environmental Protection. The proposed Project aims at assisting Hungary meet the latter objective. PART II. THE POWER SECTOR A. Legal Framework 2.1 Act XLVIII of 1994 sets the regime governing the power sector in Hungary. I Under the Act, the Government establishes energy policy, and retains certain rights such as the approval (through Parliament) of new power plants in excess of 600 MW and of fuels selection in new plants in excess of 200 MW; and fixes the tariffs. The sector is regulated by the Hungarian Energy Office (HEO), established under the Gas Supply Act.2 HEO is inter alia in charge of enforcing the Electricity Act, approving the contractual framework, protecting consumers, issuing licenses and administering those. The Act sets the principles under which electricity tariffs will be established effective January 1, 1997 (i.e., recovery of reasonable investment and operating costs including standby capacity, environment protection, decommissioning, safety etc.). While tariffs are promulgated by the Government, their preparation and application are the responsibility of HEO. B. Institutional Aspects 2.2 The Hungarian power sector has undergone considerable restructuring in recent years. Until 1991, the MVM Trust constituted an integrated utility with a dominant role in the sector. Effective 1992, MVM was established as a holding company, with 15 subsidiaries (a nuclear power plant - PAKS, 7 conventional generators, 6 distributors, one transmission operation and maintenance company - OVIT), most of which were jointly owned with the State (through APV Rt). During 1995-96: (i) the six distribution companies together with three conventional generation companies were partially privatized; and (ii) MVM swapped shares in the distribution companies against shares in PAKS (the nuclear power plant) and OVIT (the transmission maintenance company). As a result, MVM is for all practical purposes the full owner of PAKS and OVIT, and retains shares in seven conventional generators. During 1997, the Government will attempt to: (i) privatize the remaining four conventional generators; and (ii) sell part of its stake in MVM (the Government has decided to retain majority control over MVM). A Government Resolution3 provides that MVM will dispose of all of its shares in the generators by the end of 1998 (other than PAKS and secondary reserves). Annex 2.1 describes the reform program in more detail. 2.3 MVM plays a central role in the power sector being entrusted with transmission, dispatch, and generation planning. In this capacity, it buys power from the generators under long term contractual arrangements, ensures that the safety and reliability standards of the network are complied with, and sells power to the distributors under similar long term arrangements. Furthermore, tariffs continued to contain significant distortions - for instance the capacity charge of the generators to MVM is considerably above that of MVM to the distributors, which is itself often above that charged to ultimate consumers (the deficit is recovered through considerably higher energy fees). PART III. THE BORROWER A. Corporate Objectives 3.1 MVM is still in a transition phase from a fully integrated utility in charge of the whole sector, to a transmission-dispatch-planning company operating in a commercial environment in conjunction with a large number of private entities. Project Objective 4.1 One of the main objectives of the Hungarian energy policy in the 1990s is the interconnection of the Hungarian power system with the Western European power pool (UCPTE), to ensure a desirable level of security of supply at the lowest possible cost. As a first step in the process of interconnection, MVM joined the Polish, Czech and Slovak power companies to form the Central European Power Pool (CENTREL) in the fall of 1992. On October 18, 1995, A comprehensive independent environmental audit of MVM (and the generators) was initiated in 1995, and has been largely completed. .
 - 12 - CENTREL joined UCPTE on a trial basis, and the two systems have been operating in parallel ever since. 4.2 The objective of the Project is thus to provide about 200 MW of generation reserve capacity to enable Hungary to maintain a level of reliability and security of supply in line with international standards. Under UCPTE's operating rules, each member company is responsible for providing sufficient primary control reserves (immediate response) and secondary control reserves (within-15-minutes response) of generating capacity to maintain system frequency and restore scheduled tie-line flows ( export-import balance) in the event of the loss of its largest unit. In the Hungarian power system, the largest generating units are the 460-MW units at PAKS nuclear power station. In the event of the loss of one of these units, only about 100 MW can be supplied from the Hungarian system's own available spinning reserve capacity. The remaining 360 MW required must come from imports (about 160 MW) and 200 MW of new domestic power plants. MVM's feasibility studies indicate that the quick start gas turbine power plants in the proposed project are the least cost means of supplying the 200 MW of required domestic generating capacity. B. Of all the countries in Eastern Europe, Hungary has gone furthest in restructuring its power sector, and privatizing power utilities. Corporate Restructuring 2. Until end-1991, the Hungarian power sector was integrated under the MVM Trust. As such the trust owned and operated all the facilities in the country. On December 31, 1991, the MVM Trust was incorporated into MVM, the national grid company, six regional distribution companies, seven conventional power generation companies, and one nuclear power generation company (PAKS). Nearly all the shares of MVM were entrusted to what is known today as APV Rt, the Hungarian State Privatization and Holding Company Ltd. 3. Ownership of the six distributors was initially assigned to MVM (50%), APV Rt (47-49%), and municipalities (2-3%). Following the integration of a number of coal mines with power plants, the ownership of the generators was assigned to APV Rt (34- 50%), MVM (35-50%), SZESZEK (0-21%), municipalities (0-9%) and other entities (0-18%). The golden shares grant the Government special rights aimed essentially at preventing major changes in the institutional framework. Thus the approval of the holder of the golden share is required to decrease the registered capital of a company, modify its main purpose, merge or transfer to another company significant activities and issue stock. The 2.4 hectares project site is located in the outskirts of Liter village approximately 1 km North-North-East from the settlement (1850 inhabitants) in the Transdanubian (Dunantul) region, about 95 km South-West from Budapest. To N.W. from Liter the region is bordered by the Veszprem highland, to S.E. by the Balaton highland and the Vilonya hills. Lake Balaton, one of the most important recreation areas, is about 5-6 km from the site. Within the geographical environment of the project site there are four more settlements (S61y, Vilonya, Balatonfuzfo, Kiralyszentisva 300, 600, 5300, 300 inhabitants, respectively). 2. The deterrnining morphological element of the natural landscape is a dolomite range in NE-SW direction. Treeless parts of the rocky surface are covered with thin soil. The Northem part is a highland of an average altitude of 200 m (BSL). The surface is interrupted by small cone-shaped formations and ridges. The dolomite range is almost cut into two parts by the so-called "great structural line of Liter" followed by the Bendola creek. Along the line there have been seismic activities that can be characterized by a maximum activity of 6-7 and 0.15 acceleration of 100 year frequency. In the geological construction of the area the base rock can be found directly under the thin topsoil; limestone, dolomite, and, at some places, lime marl with clay marl inclusions. The most important water resources in the area are the karstic waters in the carbonate deposit that forms the base rock of the Bakony mountains. The springs come to the surface at an altitude of 200 m (BSL) or over. The springwaters flow in E, SE direction corresponding to the slope. The Bendola-creek having its source in the great structural zone runs in the wide erosion bed. Environment status aimatic Conditions 3. The yearly average temperature in the region is about 10 C (2.3 to 26.6). Relative humidity varies between 62 to 83%. Rainy days of the year amounts to 120. The most likely wind directions are N-NW (14.4%) and NW (13.7%); the average wind velocity is about 3 m/s.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Quick Start Gas Turbine Project is to provide about 200 Megawatt (MW) of generation reserve capacity to enable Hungary to maintain a level of reliability and security of supply in line with international standards. The project consists of two complete single cycle gas turbine power plants rated at about 110 MW each, burning light distillate fuel oil. The plants will consist of the following fully integrated components: 1) main equipment (gas turbine and generator sets and auxiliaries, air inlet, exhaust gas systems, including stacks, electrical equipment, power plant control system, high voltage switch gear and unit transformers, enclosures and light structure buildings); 2) auxiliary systems (fuel supply system, demineralized water supply, water supply for extinguishing system, fire detection and protection system, telecommunications and remote and indication systems); 3) civil works (site preparation, leveling, earthwork, foundations, roads and fences, site improvements, cable and piping channels and trenches); and 4) network and infrastructure (telecommunications link).
